Tweet-sized Case Summary

Small Group Task

Take the next ten minutes and construct your own version of the tax letter with the members of your group.

Summary of Ideas

Consider the following: suppose you are standing in front of two restaurants, and deciding which to go into for dinner. They look the same, but one restaurant is crowded while the other is completely empty.

  • Which would you choose, and why?
  • How can it sometimes be a good thing to follow social norms?

Choice Architecture

Show of hands, how many think the letter should:

  • Focus on social norms?
  • On threat of repossession?
  • On something else?
  • How should we decide?

Experimentation

Randomization:

Random assignment of subjects ensures that there are no inherent differences between the groups answering the different questions. The differences in behavior can be attributed solely to the different questions.

Experimental Manipulation:

To learn what difference something makes in people's behavior, we vary that one thing between subjects.

Results

Social norms helped. There was 5% increase in the likelihood delinquent taxpayers submitted a payment in the weeks following their letter -- the difference of millions of pounds in revenue each year.

Switch the context

Now consider similar circumstances involving a credit card company.

  • How, if at all, should that letter differ? Why?
